title: Evaluate this Telegram post promoting a brand-new DeFi meme token. Identify if it's a scam.
content:
# Evaluate this Telegram post promoting a brand-new DeFi meme token. Identify if it's a scam.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** Telegram
**Channel_Name:** MemeCoinPromotions
**Message_Content:** Join our new token launch, FluffyInu! 100x potential within days. Liquidity locked for 24 hours only! Hurry before it’s too late: hxxp://fluffyinu[.]finance
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Suspicious DeFi meme token promotion promising quick 100x returns with only a short liquidity lock.
**Indicators:**
• Unrealistic profit claims (100x in days)
• Very short liquidity lock period
• Telegram marketing without reputable audit
• Likely rug-pull or honeypot scenario

• No legitimate documentation or audit link

**Description:** User demands account sharing or remote access, clearly risky. Likely leads to item/gold theft or ban for real-money trading.
**Indicators:**
• Requires direct account sharing or remote control
• Violates game’s Terms of Service on real-money deals
• Unverifiable guarantee of kills
• High potential for account compromise

title: Evaluate if this direct message about a 'WoW Arena tournament entry' is legitimate or a con.
content:
# Evaluate if this direct message about a 'WoW Arena tournament entry' is legitimate or a con.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** Discord DM
**Sender_Username:** ArenaOfficial#2222
**Message_Content:** Pay 50k gold to register for the official Blizzard Arena Cup. Hurry, bracket spots are limited!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Fake 'official' tournament demanding in-game gold as a registration fee, likely pocketing the gold with no real event.
**Indicators:**
• No official Blizzard event references or website
• In-game gold registration fee is unusual for official tournaments
• Pressuring FOMO approach (limited spots)
• Likely a player-run scam with no real bracket

title: Check if a 'guaranteed boss drop run' for Diablo 4 requiring real currency upfront is a scam or legit.
content:
# Check if a 'guaranteed boss drop run' for Diablo 4 requiring real currency upfront is a scam or legit.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** community forum (Diablo 4)
**Poster_Username:** BossRunSeller
**Post_Content:** Pay me $20 via PayPal, I'll carry you in the next World Boss kill for guaranteed legendary drops.
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Charging real money for a carry with 'guaranteed' legendary is suspicious and not officially recognized—likely a scam without recourse.
**Indicators:**
• Real money transaction for a chance-based drop
• Unfounded guarantee about random drop mechanics
• No official third-party escrow or verification
• Likely no service provided after payment

title: Analyze if a 'boost your clan rank' advertisement in RuneScape is a legitimate service or a trick.
content:
# Analyze if a 'boost your clan rank' advertisement in RuneScape is a legitimate service or a trick.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** in-game clan chat (RuneScape)
**Sender_Username:** RankBoosterVIP
**Message_Content:** Pay 3 bonds, and I'll talk to the clan owner to make you a general. I've done it for others!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Offers clan rank for bonds or real currency with no official mechanism—likely a scam with no actual clan authority.
**Indicators:**
• Promises rank that typically only clan leadership can grant
• Demands in-game currency or items upfront
• Claim of special influence not verifiable
• Likely keeps the bonds without fulfilling the rank

title: Assess if this Kickstarter-like campaign for a 'WoW private server' is legitimate or not.
content:
# Assess if this Kickstarter-like campaign for a 'WoW private server' is legitimate or not.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** Crowdfunding site
**Project_Title:** WoW: Nostalgia Private Server
**Description:** We need $10,000 to launch our private server. Your donation gets you VIP gear and GM commands!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Project aims to create an unauthorized private server, offering 'GM commands' for donors—likely to vanish or break Blizzard rules.
**Indicators:**
• Violation of Blizzard's TOS (private servers)
• Promises GM-level privileges for money
• Crowdfunding with no transparent progress or licensing
• High chance of a 'cash grab' never delivered

title: Identify if this 'Diablo 4 clan synergy' requiring a sponsor fee is suspicious.
content:
# Identify if this 'Diablo 4 clan synergy' requiring a sponsor fee is suspicious.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** in-game chat (Diablo 4)
**Sender_Username:** ClanMasterUSA
**Message_Content:** Our clan offers synergy runs and weekly legendary gifts. Just pay a 1M gold sponsor fee to join!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Clan demands high sponsor fee for promised 'weekly legendary gifts,' which are not guaranteed by the game’s loot system.
**Indicators:**
• Upfront large gold requirement for membership
• Claims of guaranteed legendary items (random drops in Diablo 4)
• No transparent breakdown of how 'gifts' are provided
• Likely a gold grab with no real benefit

title: Evaluate this message offering a direct item trade from Diablo 2 to Diablo 4. Could it be a scam?
content:
# Evaluate this message offering a direct item trade from Diablo 2 to Diablo 4. Could it be a scam?
## Threat Example:
**Source:** Discord server message
**Sender_Username:** CrossGameTrader#0011
**Message_Content:** I can convert your Diablo 2 runes into Diablo 4 gold. 100% legit. Just send me your account details so I can do the swap.
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** No official cross-game item trading. Asking for account details to 'swap' is a clear attempt to compromise the account.
**Indicators:**
• Claiming cross-franchise item transfer (not a real feature)
• Needs full login to complete transaction
• Likely an account theft approach
• Preys on players seeking easy resource transfers

title: Analyze if this WoW gold giveaway for following a Twitch channel is a legitimate promotion.
content:
# Analyze if this WoW gold giveaway for following a Twitch channel is a legitimate promotion.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** Twitch chat
**Channel_Name:** StreamerX
**Chat_Message:** Follow now and whisper your Blizzard login details to claim 5,000 gold. Hurry, only for first 50 followers!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Streamer or impersonator requesting Blizzard login details for a 'gold giveaway,' strongly indicative of a phishing scam.
**Indicators:**
• Request for sensitive login info as part of a 'giveaway'
• Unusual to require login details to deliver in-game gold
• No official Blizzard or Twitch procedure
• Likely channel impersonator or compromised account

title: Determine if this RuneScape house party claiming free construction training is real or a trap.
content:
# Determine if this RuneScape house party claiming free construction training is real or a trap.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** in-game friend chat (RuneScape)
**Sender_Username:** PartyHost99
**Message_Content:** Come to my house for free Construction exp! Just pay 1M GP for 'entry fee'—we’ll skill together!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Claims free Construction XP but requires a large 'entry fee.' Likely no actual training or benefit, just gold theft.
**Indicators:**
• Requires upfront 'entry fee' with no explanation
• Promises 'free XP' but charges 1M GP ironically
• Likely never repays or provides real benefit
• Common scamming tactic disguised as a party or drop event

title: Check if this Diablo 3 ladder rank boosting offer with remote desktop login is legitimate.
content:
# Check if this Diablo 3 ladder rank boosting offer with remote desktop login is legitimate.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** gaming forum post (Diablo 3)
**Poster_Username:** LadderChampion
**Post_Content:** I’ll get you top 10 on the ladder! Let me remote into your PC and run rifts for you. Payment via PayPal friends & family only.
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** User demands remote PC access and a non-refundable payment method—very risky and likely a con or account theft method.
**Indicators:**
• Remote desktop access to victim’s computer
• Payment method is 'friends & family' (no buyer protection)
• Unverifiable claim of top 10 ladder rank
• High chance of theft or scam

title: Analyze if this WoW in-game community event link is actually a phishing site.
content:
# Analyze if this WoW in-game community event link is actually a phishing site.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** in-game chat (WoW)
**Sender_Username:** CommunityEventLead
**Message_Content:** Register for the official WoW Community Day: hxxp://wow-event-community[.]io. Free mount for all sign-ups!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** External link offering a free mount for 'community day'—Blizzard events are typically on official domains.
**Indicators:**
• Fake domain (wow-event-community[.]io)
• No mention on official Blizzard channels
• Promised mount for sign-ups (rare or exclusive items not given this way)
• Likely phishing or data collection

title: Evaluate if this new Diablo 4 clan's request for 'ID or passport photo for clan verification' is normal or suspicious.
content:
# Evaluate if this new Diablo 4 clan's request for 'ID or passport photo for clan verification' is normal or suspicious.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** Discord server message
**Sender_Username:** D4ClanMaster#0101
**Message_Content:** To join, send ID photo so we can confirm you're not a troll. We keep it on file for security.
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Outrageous demand for real-life ID documents to join a gaming clan, likely an identity theft tactic.
**Indicators:**
• No legitimate reason to collect personal ID for a clan
• Potential identity or personal data theft attempt
• Red flag to 'keep it on file' with no official capacity
• Gross invasion of privacy well beyond typical clan requirements

title: Check this RuneScape forum exchange about 'selling large clan treasury' for PayPal. Safe or scam?
content:
# Check this RuneScape forum exchange about 'selling large clan treasury' for PayPal. Safe or scam?
## Threat Example:
**Source:** unofficial trading forum
**Poster_Username:** ClanTreasureSale
**Post_Content:** Our clan is quitting; we have 1 billion GP in treasury. Sell for PayPal $500. You go first—trusted seller!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Massive GP sale with questionable 'trust me' approach, demanding buyer to pay first—commonly a sign of no delivery scam.
**Indicators:**
• Huge gold amount for below market rate
• No middleman or escrow recommended
• Insists buyer go first on a random forum
• Likely never delivers gold after receiving money

title: Determine if this in-game Diablo 2 Resurrected message about 'upgrade your items' is a hack attempt.
content:
# Determine if this in-game Diablo 2 Resurrected message about 'upgrade your items' is a hack attempt.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** in-game chat (Diablo 2R)
**Sender_Username:** ItemUpgrader
**Message_Content:** Give me your runeword gear, I'll recast it with a new hidden rune to double stats. 100% legit secret!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Player claims they can add a hidden rune to double item stats, an impossible game mechanic. Scam to steal gear.
**Indicators:**
• False claim of hidden or special runes not recognized in official game data
• Requests transfer of valuable gear with no guarantee of return
• No legitimate ‘double stats’ system in Diablo 2
• Likely runs off with the items

title: Analyze a WoW trade channel advertisement for 'legacy mount codes' at half price. Possible scam?
content:
# Analyze a WoW trade channel advertisement for 'legacy mount codes' at half price. Possible scam?
## Threat Example:
**Source:** in-game trade chat (WoW)
**Sender_Username:** MountSellerX
**Message_Content:** Get TCG legacy mounts for half price. Pay gold or PayPal, message me now. Guaranteed working codes!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Offers TCG mount codes at a fraction of their usual price, likely invalid or already redeemed codes, scamming players out of gold or cash.
**Indicators:**
• High-value TCG items at suspiciously low cost
• Payment outside official Blizzard store or TCG redemption
• No safe trade method (like guaranteed AH item or official marketplace)
• Common code resale scam

title: Evaluate if a 'Diablo Immortal top clan membership' requiring personal info is legitimate or risky.
content:
# Evaluate if a 'Diablo Immortal top clan membership' requiring personal info is legitimate or risky.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** Reddit post (r/DiabloImmortal)
**Poster_Username:** TopClanRecruit
**Post_Content:** Join the #1 clan. Fill out this Google Form with your real name, phone number, and Blizz login. We do thorough checks!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Clan recruitment form asking for unnecessary personal data (real name, phone, login) is highly suspect for phishing.
**Indicators:**
• Excessive personal data requested
• No official or third-party verification needed for clan membership typically
• Possible identity and account theft attempt
• No legitimate reason to gather real name or phone

title: Decide if this direct message about a 'RuneScape account recovery service' is legitimate or a scam.
content:
# Decide if this direct message about a 'RuneScape account recovery service' is legitimate or a scam.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** in-game private message (RuneScape)
**Sender_Username:** RecoveryExpertRS
**Message_Content:** Struggling to recover your old RS account? I can do it for you. Just share your email and previous passwords with me!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** User offers 'recovery service' but demands all account recovery details, enabling them to hijack the account instead.
**Indicators:**
• Asks for old passwords and email (full recovery details)
• No official Jagex partnership or user support credentials
• Likely to permanently claim the account after obtaining info
• Exploitative tactic targeting players with lost accounts

title: Analyze if this 'secret Discord code' can unlock Diablo 4 expansions for free. Real or scammy?
content:
# Analyze if this 'secret Discord code' can unlock Diablo 4 expansions for free. Real or scammy?
## Threat Example:
**Source:** Discord server message
**Sender_Username:** Expansion4Free#4455
**Message_Content:** Enter code FREED4EXP at hxxp://blizz-claim[.]info to get expansions added automatically. 1 day only!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Fake code to 'unlock expansions' on a suspicious site. Likely phishing for Battle.net credentials or payment info.
**Indicators:**
• Promises free expansions outside official channels
• Dubious domain (blizz-claim[.]info)
• Sense of urgency with a 1-day limit
• Could harvest login credentials or personal data

title: Check if this WoW 'recruit a friend' link from an unknown user is safe or a phishing link.
content:
# Check if this WoW 'recruit a friend' link from an unknown user is safe or a phishing link.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** email
**Sender_Email:** raf@wowconnect[.]com
**Subject:** Join me in World of Warcraft, get a free month!
**Body:** Click here: hxxp://wowconnect[.]com/raf-offer. Enter your Blizzard login to claim your free month.
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Fake recruit-a-friend link requesting direct Blizzard login info on a non-official website, typical phishing method.
**Indicators:**
• Domain does not match official WoW or Blizzard sites
• Email from unknown user referencing free month
• Asks for login credentials outside battle.net
• Classic phish exploiting recruit-a-friend system

title: Identify if this RuneScape message about a 'PP reward' (player moderator) is real or a con.
content:
# Identify if this RuneScape message about a 'PP reward' (player moderator) is real or a con.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** in-game system message (spoofed)
**Message_Content:** Congrats, you’ve been selected as a Player Moderator. Visit hxxp://runescape-mod-confirm[.]site to finalize!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Spoofed system message awarding player mod status, redirecting to an external site for credentials.
**Indicators:**
• Jagex does not send in-game system messages with third-party links
• Fake mod invitation with no official Jagex domain
• Likely credentials or personal data theft attempt
• Exploits desire for mod privileges

title: Analyze this whisper in Diablo 4 about a 'clan bank' deposit for future item draws. Is it safe?
content:
# Analyze this whisper in Diablo 4 about a 'clan bank' deposit for future item draws. Is it safe?
## Threat Example:
**Source:** in-game Diablo 4 whisper
**Sender_Username:** ClanTreasurer
**Message_Content:** Deposit 500k gold into the clan bank for random legendary draws. The more you deposit, the better your odds!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Unverified 'clan bank' deposit system for random legendaries. No official Diablo 4 clan bank mechanic, likely gold theft.
**Indicators:**
• No official in-game clan bank feature with random draws
• Encourages higher deposits for better odds
• No legitimate method to convert gold to guaranteed items
• Likely pure scam collecting gold

title: Examine if this announcement about a 'WoW cross-faction cross-server gold transfer' is a scam.
content:
# Examine if this announcement about a 'WoW cross-faction cross-server gold transfer' is a scam.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** in-game trade chat (WoW)
**Sender_Username:** XRealmGold
**Message_Content:** Send me your gold on Alliance, I’ll return it on Horde same server. I only charge a small handling fee.
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Player claims to handle cross-faction gold transfer with no official mechanism, likely to keep the gold without returning anything.
**Indicators:**
• No official cross-faction gold exchange (aside from specific methods on neutral AH, etc.)
• Requires trusting a random player with your gold
• Possible partial up-front fee or entire gold stolen
• Scam exploiting cross-faction trade confusion

title: Decide if this website offering 'instant Diablo 2 ladder resets' is legitimate or not.
content:
# Decide if this website offering 'instant Diablo 2 ladder resets' is legitimate or not.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** Google Ad
**Url:** hxxp://ladder-reset-quick[.]net
**Ad_Text:** Get your account reset to fresh ladder instantly. Just provide your account info!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Fake ladder reset service demanding account info. Official ladder resets occur server-side by Blizzard, not third-party sites.
**Indicators:**
• No external mechanism can reset Blizzard’s ladder
• Requests full login credentials to 'reset' the account
• Likely to steal the user’s Diablo 2 credentials
• Exploits players wanting a fresh start

title: Evaluate if this new 'RuneScape skill trainer script' requiring direct injection is safe or a cheat scam.
content:
# Evaluate if this new 'RuneScape skill trainer script' requiring direct injection is safe or a cheat scam.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** botting forum post
**Poster_Username:** SkillBotMaster
**Post_Content:** Inject this .dll into your RuneScape client for 99 in all skills within a week. Zero ban risk!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Unverified .dll injection cheat likely containing malware or keyloggers, plus guaranteed ban risk if used.
**Indicators:**
• DLL injection approach with no credible developer
• Promise of 'zero ban risk' is untrue
• High likelihood of account compromise or infostealer
• Cheating typically violates TOS, risking bans

Analyze this email impersonating the CEO, requesting a wire transfer for an urgent vendor payment.
content:
# Analyze this email impersonating the CEO, requesting a wire transfer for an urgent vendor payment.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** email
**Sender_Email:** ceo.office@outlook-proxy[.]com
**Subject:** RE: Urgent Vendor Payment
**Body:** Hello. Please transfer $25,000 to our new supplier account before noon. We risk a penalty if not done immediately.
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Email impersonating the company's CEO, pressuring an employee to wire money to an unverified account.
**Indicators:**
• External, non-corporate sender email domain
• Demand for urgent wire transfer
• Threat of penalty if not sent quickly
• Spoofed CEO identity

title: Decide if this phone call, claiming to be the HR director, is a scam. The caller asks for employee payroll info.
content:
# Decide if this phone call, claiming to be the HR director, is a scam. The caller asks for employee payroll info.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** phone call
**Caller_Id:** Blocked
**Claimed_Identity:** HR Director
**Scenario:** Caller claims to need immediate access to payroll records due to a system error.
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Fraudster impersonating HR director via phone, requesting sensitive payroll data with no formal verification.
**Indicators:**
• Blocked caller ID
• Urgent demand for payroll info
• No established authentication method
• Impersonation of HR leadership

title: Identify red flags in this email from 'Accounts Dept' about a supplier invoice with updated bank details.
content:
# Identify red flags in this email from 'Accounts Dept' about a supplier invoice with updated bank details.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** email
**Sender_Email:** accounts@my-supplier-updates[.]net
**Subject:** Updated Bank Details for Invoice #4512
**Body:** Please note our new bank details for invoice #4512. Kindly make the payment ASAP to avoid delays.
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Invoice scam email requesting payment to a newly provided bank account, impersonating a known supplier.
**Indicators:**
• Domain mismatch or unknown domain
• Unsolicited request to change bank details
• Pressure to pay quickly
• Likely compromised or spoofed vendor account

title: Examine this text message claiming to be from HR, asking for employee Social Security numbers. Classify it.
content:
# Examine this text message claiming to be from HR, asking for employee Social Security numbers. Classify it.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** SMS
**Sender_Number:** +1-404-HR-VERIFY
**Message_Text:** HR ALERT: We need your SSN immediately to finalize new benefits. Reply now.
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Text message impersonating HR, requesting SSNs from employees without proper procedure.
**Indicators:**
• Unsolicited request for SSN
• No official HR contact method
• Pressure to respond immediately via SMS
• Attempt to gather sensitive personal data

title: Determine whether this email from the CFO about an urgent bill payment to an unknown vendor is legitimate.
content:
# Determine whether this email from the CFO about an urgent bill payment to an unknown vendor is legitimate.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** email
**Sender_Email:** cfo.emergency@fake-company[.]top
**Subject:** Urgent Bill Payment Needed - Invoice #X701
**Body:** We must pay an outstanding invoice immediately. Transfer $10,000 to the attached account details.
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** BEC email impersonating CFO, demanding immediate payment for a suspicious invoice.
**Indicators:**
• Urgent tone from CFO with unfamiliar domain
• Vague references to invoice details
• Pressure to bypass standard approval protocols
• Potential BEC (Business Email Compromise)

title: Analyze this voicemail from an individual claiming to be an external HR consultant, requesting employee tax info.
content:
# Analyze this voicemail from an individual claiming to be an external HR consultant, requesting employee tax info.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** voicemail
**Caller_Id:** Unknown
**Message_Content:** This is the new HR consultant. I need the W-2 forms for all employees. Please call back with the data.
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Unknown caller masquerading as HR consultant, aiming to obtain employee tax forms (W-2) for identity theft.
**Indicators:**
• No official introduction or reference from real HR
• Demand for bulk sensitive employee data
• Caller ID unknown or restricted
• Potential attempt to gather personal info on employees

title: Identify whether this email from 'Legal Department' about a past-due invoice is part of an invoice scam.
content:
# Identify whether this email from 'Legal Department' about a past-due invoice is part of an invoice scam.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** email
**Sender_Email:** legaldept@company-collections[.]com
**Subject:** Final Notice: Past-Due Invoice #8812
**Body:** Your account is in arrears for invoice #8812. Pay immediately to avoid legal repercussions.
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Phony collections threat, pressuring the recipient to pay a suspicious invoice or face alleged legal actions.
**Indicators:**
• No official company domain or internal references
• Threatening legal language for immediate payment
• Lack of official invoice documentation or history
• Likely fake invoice to intimidate quick payment

title: Determine if this LinkedIn message from 'HR Specialist' about verifying personal bank info is a scam.
content:
# Determine if this LinkedIn message from 'HR Specialist' about verifying personal bank info is a scam.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** social media (LinkedIn)
**Sender_Profile:** HR Specialist at BigCorp Inc.
**Message_Content:** We need to finalize your direct deposit. Please send your full bank account details here in chat.
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Fake HR request on LinkedIn asking for sensitive financial info via chat, a strong sign of phishing.
**Indicators:**
• Unsolicited request for direct deposit details
• No secure portal or official HR system used
• Likely impersonation or unauthorized approach
• Attempts to gather personal banking info quickly

title: Evaluate this phone call claiming to be from the finance department, instructing a vendor payment change.
content:
# Evaluate this phone call claiming to be from the finance department, instructing a vendor payment change.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** phone call
**Caller_Id:** +1-888-NEW-ACCT
**Scenario:** Caller demands the AP clerk update vendor bank details to a new account, effective immediately.
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Call instructing an urgent vendor bank detail change, likely a BEC tactic to reroute payments.
**Indicators:**
• Insistence on immediate banking update
• No official request or email from recognized domain
• Caller ID does not match known internal lines
• High risk of payment diversion to a fraudulent account

title: Classify this email request from a CFO about purchasing gift cards as suspicious or valid.
content:
# Classify this email request from a CFO about purchasing gift cards as suspicious or valid.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** email
**Sender_Email:** cfo.urgent@companyfinance[.]info
**Subject:** Gift Cards Needed for Client
**Body:** Please buy $2,000 in Amazon gift cards and send me the codes ASAP for a client appreciation event.
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Gift card scam impersonating CFO, requesting codes that can be instantly redeemed, a classic CEO/CFO fraud approach.
**Indicators:**
• Unfamiliar domain extension (.info)
• Unusual or urgent request for gift cards
• No official procedure or PO for purchase
• Frequent hallmark of BEC/CEO scams

title: Analyze this email about a 'management-level pay adjustment' from a suspicious HR domain. Scam or not?
content:
# Analyze this email about a 'management-level pay adjustment' from a suspicious HR domain. Scam or not?
## Threat Example:
**Source:** email
**Sender_Email:** hr.review@unknown-hrportal[.]co
**Subject:** Management Pay Adjustment Notice
**Body:** We have processed a raise for your position. Confirm your bank details to receive backpay.
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Phishing email impersonating HR, luring employees with a fake pay raise to obtain financial credentials.
**Indicators:**
• Unknown domain not matching official HR/Company domain
• Promise of unexpected pay raise requiring account info
• Likely leads to phishing form or direct data request
• Tactic exploiting employee excitement about raises

title: Identify red flags in a text message telling an employee they must pay a 'uniform fee' via a provided link.
content:
# Identify red flags in a text message telling an employee they must pay a 'uniform fee' via a provided link.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** SMS
**Sender_Number:** Workplace Alert
**Message_Text:** HR: Uniform fee is overdue. Pay $100 now at hxxp://hr-pay-fees[.]biz or face payroll deduction.
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Threatening text claiming a uniform fee is overdue, directing to a suspicious payment site.
**Indicators:**
• Unofficial, suspicious URL
• Threat of payroll deduction if not paid promptly
• No prior notice or official email about uniform fees
• Likely a scam to capture payment info

title: Evaluate the authenticity of an in-person courier delivering a sealed envelope with an invoice and a new bank account.

**Source:** in-person
**Scenario:** Courier claims urgent invoice re-issue, instructing accounts payable to wire funds to the enclosed bank detail.

**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Physical scam attempt: unsolicited courier delivers a changed invoice with new bank info, urging immediate payment.

**Description:** BEC attempt via SMS, pushing an urgent vendor payment through a dubious short link.
**Indicators:**
• No official phone or internal verification method

• Generic text demanding payment outside normal channels
• Likely smishing link to collect credentials or direct funds

# Analyze this Twitter DM offering a free subscription to an OnlyFans creator. Is it legitimate or a scam?

• Likely phishing or credit card data capture attempt

title: Examine a random DM from a user guaranteeing an 'OnlyFans monetization method' if you buy their eBook. Scam or legit?
content:
# Examine a random DM from a user guaranteeing an 'OnlyFans monetization method' if you buy their eBook. Scam or legit?
## Threat Example:
**Source:** Instagram DM
**Sender_Profile:** OF_Biz_Guru
**Message_Content:** My eBook reveals a secret glitch to monetize OnlyFans instantly. Just $39 PayPal. Guaranteed success!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** Claims a 'secret glitch' for guaranteed monetization on OnlyFans—likely snake oil eBook or worthless info.
**Indicators:**
• Exaggerated claims of guaranteed success or glitch
• Direct payment to personal PayPal or other method
• Unverified or random 'guru' user with no proven track record
• Likely worthless or non-existent product

title: Decide if this email from a self-proclaimed OnlyFans model manager offering free promotion is suspicious or real.
content:
# Decide if this email from a self-proclaimed OnlyFans model manager offering free promotion is suspicious or real.
## Threat Example:
**Source:** email
**Sender_Email:** modelmanager@of-boost[.]world
**Subject:** Boost Your OnlyFans For Free
**Body:** Let us manage your account to multiply your subscribers. We just need your login details—completely free!
## Analysis:
**Classification:** malicious
**Description:** User claims to be a 'model manager' requiring direct login to manage an OnlyFans account—common account takeover approach.
**Indicators:**
• No references or official agency affiliation
• Requesting actual OnlyFans credentials
• Free 'boost' with unrealistic promises of subscriber gains
• Likely aims to hijack or exploit the creator’s account
